name: Captain Vikram Batra
shortStory: Known as 'Sher Shah', Captain Vikram Batra displayed extraordinary courage during the Kargil conflict. His famous words 'Yeh Dil Maange More' became legendary.
fullStory: Captain Vikram Batra, PVC, was born on September 9, 1974, in Palampur, Himachal Pradesh. He was commissioned into the 13 JAK Rifles on December 6, 1997. During the Kargil War in 1999, he led one of the most difficult operations to recapture Point 5140. His fearless leadership and tactical brilliance helped secure a crucial victory. On July 7, 1999, while attempting to rescue a fellow officer, he made the ultimate sacrifice. His last words 'Jai Mata Di' and his battle cry 'Yeh Dil Maange More' continue to inspire soldiers. He was posthumously awarded the Param Vir Chakra, India's highest military honor.
familyBackground: Son of Girdhari Lal Batra and Kamal Kanta Batra
motto: Either I will come back after hoisting the Tricolor, or I will come back wrapped in it, but I will be back for sure.

name: Major Sandeep Unnikrishnan
shortStory: Major Sandeep fought terrorists during the 26/11 Mumbai attacks, saving countless lives at the Taj Hotel before making the ultimate sacrifice.
fullStory: Major Sandeep Unnikrishnan, AC, was born on March 15, 1977, in Kozhikode, Kerala. He was commissioned into the 7 Bihar Regiment and later joined the elite National Security Guard (NSG). During the 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks, he led his team into the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel to neutralize terrorists. His tactical expertise and courage saved numerous hostages. On November 28, 2008, while engaging terrorists on the sixth floor, he was fatally wounded but continued fighting until his last breath. His famous words to his father, 'Do not come up, I will handle them,' showed his dedication to duty. He was posthumously awarded the Ashoka Chakra for his supreme sacrifice.
familyBackground: Son of K. Unnikrishnan and Dhanalakshmi Unnikrishnan
education: Frank Anthony Public School, NDA Khadakwasla
motto: Never give up, and never give in

name: Company Havildar Major Abdul Hamid
shortStory: Abdul Hamid single-handedly destroyed seven Pakistani tanks with his recoilless gun, earning the title 'Hero of Asal Uttar'.
fullStory: Company Havildar Major Abdul Hamid, PVC, was born on July 1, 1933, in Dhamupur village, Ghazipur, Uttar Pradesh. He was enrolled in the 4 Grenadiers on December 27, 1954. During the 1965 Indo-Pakistani War, at the Battle of Asal Uttar, he displayed exceptional courage and tactical brilliance. Armed with a 106mm recoilless gun mounted on a jeep, he single-handedly destroyed seven Pakistani Patton tanks. His actions were instrumental in India's victory at Asal Uttar, which became known as the 'graveyard of Patton tanks.' On September 10, 1965, while engaging the eighth tank, he was killed by enemy fire. His sacrifice and heroism earned him the Param Vir Chakra posthumously.
familyBackground: Son of Usman and Rasoolan Bibi

name: Subedar Joginder Singh
shortStory: Subedar Joginder Singh led three heroic counter-attacks against heavily armed Chinese forces at Tongpen La, valiantly fighting with unmatched courage and determination until his very last breath defending the nation.
fullStory: Subedar Joginder Singh, PVC, was born on September 26, 1921, in Mehlanwali village, Moga district, Punjab. He was enrolled in the 1 Sikh Regiment on September 21, 1936. During the 1962 Sino-Indian War, his platoon was tasked with defending the Tongpen La pass in NEFA. Despite being heavily outnumbered, he led three successive counter-attacks against Chinese forces. In the first attack, he bayonet-charged the enemy, inflicting heavy casualties. In the second attack, though wounded, he continued to lead from the front. In the final attack, despite severe injuries, he fought with a bayonet until he was overpowered and captured. He later died in Chinese custody. His extraordinary courage and leadership earned him the Param Vir Chakra posthumously.
familyBackground: Son of Thakur Dass Singh and Nihal Kaur
motto: Deg Tegh Fateh (Victory to charity and arms)

name: Captain Manoj Kumar Pandey
shortStory: Captain Manoj Kumar Pandey led the assault on Jubar Top with extraordinary courage, clearing enemy bunkers before making the ultimate sacrifice.
fullStory: Captain Manoj Kumar Pandey, PVC, was born on June 25, 1975, in Rudha village, Sitapur district, Uttar Pradesh. He was commissioned into the 1/11 Gorkha Rifles on June 12, 1998. During the Kargil War, he was tasked with capturing Jubar Top, a strategic height in the Batalik sector. Leading from the front, he motivated his men with his fearless approach. Despite intense enemy fire, he personally cleared several enemy bunkers. On July 3, 1999, while assaulting the final enemy position, he was hit by enemy fire but continued to fight until he achieved his objective. His last words were reported to be about completing the mission. He was posthumously awarded the Param Vir Chakra for his supreme sacrifice and leadership.
familyBackground: Son of Gopi Chand Pandey and Mohini Pandey
motto: Some goals are so worthy, it's glorious even to fail

name: Flying Officer Nirmal Jit Singh Sekhon
shortStory: Flying Officer Sekhon single-handedly engaged six Pakistani Sabre jets, shooting down one before making the ultimate sacrifice defending Srinagar airfield.
fullStory: Flying Officer Nirmal Jit Singh Sekhon, PVC, was born on July 17, 1945, in Isewal village, Ludhiana district, Punjab. He was commissioned into the Indian Air Force on June 4, 1967. During the 1971 Indo-Pakistani War, on December 14, 1971, Pakistani Air Force launched a major air strike on Srinagar airfield. Sekhon was the only pilot available to scramble in his Folland Gnat fighter. Despite being heavily outnumbered (1 vs 6 Pakistani Sabres), he engaged the enemy formation fearlessly. He shot down one Pakistani Sabre and damaged another before his aircraft was hit. He continued to fight until his Gnat crashed, and he was killed. His supreme sacrifice saved the Srinagar airfield from destruction. He became the only member of the Indian Air Force to be awarded the Param Vir Chakra.
familyBackground: Son of Warrant Officer Inder Singh Sekhon
education: Government College Ludhiana, Air Force Academy

name: Naik Jadunath Singh
shortStory: Naik Jadunath Singh fought valiantly against Chinese forces in Ladakh, holding his position against overwhelming odds until his last breath.
fullStory: Naik Jadunath Singh, PVC, was born on November 21, 1916, in Shahjahanpur, Uttar Pradesh. He was enrolled in the 1 Rajput Regiment and served with distinction for many years. During the 1962 Sino-Indian War, his unit was deployed in the harsh terrain of Ladakh. On November 18, 1962, Chinese forces launched a massive attack on his post. Despite being heavily outnumbered and facing intense artillery fire, Naik Jadunath Singh held his ground. He fought with exceptional courage, inflicting heavy casualties on the enemy. Even when wounded, he continued to fight until he was killed in action. His sacrifice and determination in the face of overwhelming odds exemplified the highest traditions of the Indian Army. He was posthumously awarded the Param Vir Chakra.

name: Major Shaitan Singh
shortStory: Major Shaitan Singh led the legendary defense of Rezang La, where his company fought to the last man against Chinese forces.
fullStory: Major Shaitan Singh, PVC, was born on December 1, 1924, in Bika village near Jodhpur, Rajasthan. He was commissioned into the 13 Kumaon Regiment on April 31, 1949. During the 1962 Sino-Indian War, he commanded Charlie Company at Rezang La, a strategic pass at 16,000 feet altitude in Ladakh. On November 18, 1962, Chinese forces launched a massive attack with overwhelming numbers. Despite being heavily outnumbered, Major Shaitan Singh and his men fought with extraordinary courage. The battle became legendary as 'C' Company fought to the last man, with 114 soldiers making the ultimate sacrifice. Major Shaitan Singh, though wounded, continued to lead and inspire his men until he was killed. The Chinese suffered heavy casualties and were forced to withdraw. He was posthumously awarded the Param Vir Chakra for his exceptional leadership and sacrifice.
